Title: Basic Facts
Info: Alpacas are members of the South American Camelid Family. This includes camels, llamas, alpacas, vicunas, and guancos. Unlike llamas, which were primarily used as pack-animals, alpacas were raised for their cashmere-like fiber. They have been domesticated for over 5,000 years. Alpacas are native to the Andean Mountain Range of South America and are primarily found in Bolivia, Chile and Peru. Alpacas are often raised as an alternative to sheep farming. The importation of alpacas was stopped in 1998. The alpacas that are here are the only breeding stock to improve bloodlines. This makes breeding them a good investment opportunity.

Title: Alpaca Types
Info: There are two types of alpacas, the suri(su-ree) and the huacaya(wah-kai-yuh). The suri accounts for only 5% of alpacas in the US. It has fiber that grows quite long and forms what look like dreadlocks. The huacaya has shorter and more dense fleece, it looks similar to sheep's wool but there is no lanolin or greasiness as found in sheep's wool.

Title: Alpaca Yarn
Info: Alpaca yarn is even 1 of the most popular yarns desired by knitters at the moment. Roving fiber is common amongst hand-spinners

Title: Fibers
Info: Alpacas produce one of the world's most luxurious fibers and come in more colors than any other fiber-producing animal. They are shorn annually, in the spring, without harm to the alpaca.

Title: Padded Feet
Info: Alpacas have padded feet and are gentle on the land. They prefer to graze on tender grasses and clip them off rather than pull them from the roots.

Title: Food Consumption
Info: Alpacas are modified ruminants that convert grasses and hay to energy very efficiently and therefore eat less than most livestock.

Title: Communal Dung?
Info: Alpacas deposit their bean-like droppings in communal dung piles, controlling the spread of parasites and making pasture clean-up easy.

Title: Lifespan
Info: Alpacas average lifespan ranges 15-25 years and their average height is 3ft at their shoulders.

Title: Weight
Info: Alpacas weigh on the average 100-180 pounds which is half to one-third the size of a llama.

Title: Gestation period
Info: The alpaca's average gestation period is 335 days(11.5 months) but can go from 320-376 days.

Title: Baby Alpacas!
Info: Alpacas have single births, twins are very rare. The average weight of a newborn alpaca (cria) is 15-19 pounds. Crias stand and begin nursing within 30 minutes after delivery. Mothers(dams) are ready to rebreed as soon as 3 weeks after delivery.

Title: Alpaca Breeding
Info: Female alpacas can start breeding as early as 1 year of age. Male alpacas can begin to breed between 2-3 years of age.

Title: Many Colors
Info: Alpacas come in 22 natural colors with varing patterns.

Title: Alpaca Pens
Info: Alpacas do not require special fencing or a lot of average about 5-8 animals per acre.

Title: Social Lives
Info: Alpacas are very sociable animals and communicate to each other with humming noises, body and head movements.

Title: Grazing
Info: Alpacas are grazers and like cattle, they chew their cud. They have a split upper lip which prevents them from damaging the vegetation's roots. They require good quality hay and are supplemented with grain and mineral mixes along with fresh water daily to meet their proper nutritional requirements.
